title: 107_hr1585
content: The Act titled "Environmental Justice in Federally Assisted Housing Act" requires a study on the proximity of federally assisted housing to hazardous waste sites. The advisory commission established by the "Environmental Justice in Federally Assisted Housing Act" will study federally assisted housing to identify hazardous waste sites within the covered area, assess any history of failure to contain hazardous substances on site, and analyze the demographic composition of residents in these housing units. The advisory commission will study hazardous waste sites in federally assisted housing areas, assess health risks associated with the sites, and report findings to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The Act requires an interim report on the study method and initial results within a year, and a final report with conclusive results within 2 years of enactment. The Act establishes an Advisory Commission. The Advisory Commission on the Proximity of Hazardous Waste Sites to Federally Assisted Housing is established to conduct studies, advise the Secretary, make recommendations for federally assisted housing programs, and survey agencies for health and safety risks. The Advisory Commission on the Proximity of Hazardous Waste Sites to Federally Assisted Housing consists of 7 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. They are tasked with advising the Secretary on health and safety risks related to hazardous waste sites and recommending research for ensuring safe federally assisted housing. The Advisory Commission on the Proximity of Hazardous Waste Sites to Federally Assisted Housing consists of 7 members appointed by various officials. Appointees must have expertise in environmental law, public housing, or public health. Each member serves a 3-year term on the commission. The Advisory Commission on the Proximity of Hazardous Waste Sites to Federally Assisted Housing appoints members for varying term lengths based on their designated roles. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term, and members can serve beyond their term until a successor is appointed. The Advisory Commission on the Proximity of Hazardous Waste Sites to Federally Assisted Housing appoints members who select a chairperson from among them. The Commission meets at least 3 times a year, with a majority forming a quorum. Members who are federal officers or employees serve without additional compensation, while others are compensated at a specified rate. Members of the advisory commission shall be compensated at a rate not exceeding the daily equivalent of grade GS-18 of the General Schedule. They will also receive travel expenses and per diem. The Secretary will provide necessary resources for the commission to carry out its duties effectively. The advisory commission will terminate on December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this Act, definitions include "advisory commission," "covered area," "federally assisted housing," and "hazardous waste site." The term "site" refers to locations listed on the National Priorities List under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, or sites that have undergone assessments by the Environmental Protection Agency for possible listing. This definition also includes sites meeting these criteria after the enactment of this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
